page.title: 06TOURISM IN SHERIFF HUTTON
page.content: Originally called "Hoton",a town on a hill,"Sheriff"was prefixed when de Bulmer was appionted Sheriff of Yorkshire,1139,and built the first castle in the village.The oldest inhabitants still refer to the 'Town.' Skegmer Bank and Dasket Hill are Anglo Saxon names.Lillings Ambo is mediaeval English:-Lilling,the home;Ambo,Latin for "both",i.e.East and West Lilling. A resently restored alabaster tomb in the church is believed to be that of Prince Edward,D.1484,young son of Richard III and Anne Neville(daughter of Warwick,Kingmaker,owner of the castle).Members of the Richard III society,including Americans,are frequent visitors to the tomb.The castle,although privately owned,is a focal point for visitors.Sheriff Hutton lies on a pleasent road used by tourists travelling north from York
